title: Brexit: What happens now as Boris Johnson puts deal on ice and awaits EU delay

Boris Johnson’s Brexit deal has been put on ice after MPs scuppered his bid to rush it through Parliament in three days.

As a result, the humiliated Prime Minister finally dropped his hardline pledge to leave on October 31 - and accepted it's up to EU leaders to decide whether to delay the Halloween date.

In a major sign Brexit will now be delayed, EU Council President Donald Tusk tonight recommended that a three-month extension is accepted.

That could prompt Boris Johnson to drop his "paused" deal altogether and push for an election.

It came after a night of Commons drama just nine days before the UK is meant to leave the EU.

And yet again it leaves us all in limbo just when we thought we’d get a final decision.

So what happened tonight and what happens now? Here’s what you need to know.

What happened in the Commons tonight?

(Image: UK PARLIAMENTARY RECORDING UNIT HANDOUT/EPA-EFE/REX)

MPs voted in favour of the Withdrawal Agreement Bill at its second reading (which despite the name is its first hurdle).

This is legislation that turns Boris Johnson's Brexit deal into UK law.

In a historic move, MPs finally backed it 329-299 - which naturally is 52% to 48%.

But crucially, they voted against the ‘programme motion’.

The programme motion sets how much time the Commons has to scrutinise a Bill.

Johnson had wanted to restrict this to just three days in order to meet his “do or die” pledge to leave the EU by October 31.

MPs said that was too short for such a momentous piece of legislation and voted down the programme motion by 322 votes to 308.

Will EU leaders agree to delay Brexit?

(Image: REUTERS)

Yes, it looks like it.

European Council President Donald Tusk tonight sent a message to all 27 EU leaders telling them they should delay Brexit for three months.

This is in accordance with the request MPs forced Boris Johnson to send over the weekend.

"Boris Johnson's decision to pause the process of ratification of the Withdrawal Agreement, and in order to avoid a no-deal Brexit," Mr Tusk wrote.

"I will recommend the EU27 accept the UK request for an extension. For this I will propose a written procedure."

A written procedure suggests a special summit in Brussels would not be convened.

What happens now with the Brexit deal?

(Image: PA)

Boris Johnson had warned he would pull the whole Withdrawal Agreement Bill if he lost the vote on the programme motion.

Instead he “paused” the Bill while he waits to see what Brussels decides.

But he could now drop the Bill after all and push for an election after the EU indicated it'll back a three-month delay to January 31.

That is because he had previously threatened to do exactly that if a three-month extension was granted. He had told MPs: “I will in no way allow months more of this.

“If Parliament refuses to allow Brexit to happen, and instead gets its way and decides to delay everything until January or possibly longer, in no circumstances can the government continue with this.

“With great regret I must say the Bill will have to be pulled and we will have to go forward to a general election ."

Can Boris Johnson actually force an election?

No. No matter what he claims, he needs MPs' permission. More of this further down this article.

Can Brexit still happen on October 31?

(Image: Peter Summers)

Technically yes, but it’s very unlikely. The only way is if EU leaders refuse an extension.

Notably the PM and No10 refused to guarantee the UK will still leave on October 31. The pledge - usually throughout his speeches - was notably absent tonight.

But the PM said he would ramp up preparations for a no-deal exit just in case.

Will Brexit happen with a deal by October 31?

(Image: Peter Summers)

No.

Whatever happens Boris Johnson will now have missed this deadline, despite saying he would rather “die in a ditch” than remain in the EU after that date.

Even if the EU grants him a short extension there is no guarantee his Bill will get through Parliament in its current form.

That is because Opposition MPs have tabled amendments to the Bill.

They include calls for the UK to stay in a customs union, for a second referendum and a move to stop Johnson crashing out without a deal later down the track.

MPs who voted for the Withdrawal Bill at the second reading, including many of the 19 Labour MPs who backed it this time, could turn against it at the final showdown if these amendments are not accepted.

Will there be a general election?

(Image: Peter Summers)

That depends on the length and terms of any extension.

There are three paths to an election.

Boris Johnson could try again to overturn the Fixed Term Parliament Act but this requires a majority of two thirds of MPs (434).

This means Labour can block the move.

The second way is for Johnson to try to repeal the Act entirely but this would allow opposition parties to amend the Bill.

They could add votes at age 16 or a second referendum as the price for granting an election.

The other method is for the Prime Minister to be ousted in a vote of no confidence.

MPs would then have fourteen days in which to form an alternative government.

If that proves impossible an election follows 25 working days later.

The risk with this is either Jeremy Corbyn or a government of national unity could take over and then arrange for soft Brexit that would be put to a referendum.

How did MPs vote on the deal tonight?

(Image: PA)

MPs voted 329-299 for the second reading of the Withdrawal Agreement Bill - a majority of 30.

Bear in mind this was only a vote 'in principle' on the first steps of the Brexit deal.

Many of the 19 Labour backers were expected to back amendments on a customs union or second referendum which PM said was unacceptable. Meaning they could have turned against it later.

But it was backed by 285 Tories, 19 Labour MPs and 25 Independents - most of them ex-Tories who lost the whip last month for trying to block no-deal.

Europhile Ken Clarke, former ministers Amber Rudd, David Gauke, and author of the Letwin amendment Oliver Letwin were among those who backed the deal.

A number of former and suspended Labour MPs also voted to give the deal a reading at Committee Stage, including Kelvin Hopkins and John Woodcock.

It was opposed by 217 Labour MPs, the SNP, Plaid Cymru, the Independent Group for Change, 8 Independents and the DUP. Opponents were furious at the deal for watering down workers' rights and leaving a customs border in the Irish Sea.

Five Labour MPs abstained or did not vote - Derek Twigg, Justin Madders, Yvonne Fovargue, Ronnie Campbell and committed Brexiteer Kate Hoey. Independents Caroline Nokes and Chris Williamson also did not vote.

How did MPs vote on delay tonight?

(Image: REUTERS)

MPs voted 322-308 to reject Boris Johnson's 'programme motion' to rush his deal Bill through Parliament in three days.

It was backed by 285 Tories, 18 Independents and 5 Labour MPs - Sir Kevin Barron, Jim Fitzpatrick, Caroline Flint, Kate Hoey and John Mann.

It was opposed by 233 Labour MPs, the SNP, Lib Dems, Plaid Cymru, DUP, 15 Independents and The Independent Group for Change.

Three Labour MPs abstained or did not vote - Ronnie Campbell, Rosie Cooper and Derek Twigg. As did Independents Caroline Nokes and Chris Williamson.

What Boris Johnson's Brexit deal means - recap

Boris Johnson finally agreed a Brexit deal with the EU on 17 October 2019, though it still needs approval by MPs and is now on ice.

The 64-page list of amendments keeps a transition period up to 31 December 2020 and the £39bn divorce bill. But it scraps the Irish backstop, an insurance policy designed at preventing a hard border between Northern Ireland the Republic.

In the backstop's place would effectively be a hybrid system:

Northern Ireland and Britain would share a legal customs territory - technically forcing customs checks on goods crossing the 310-mile border with the Republic. But in practice, to avoid checks at the border, the checks will instead happen when goods reach Northern Ireland on the island of Ireland. Critics say this puts a customs border across the Irish Sea - more of this below. Northern Ireland and the Republic would share some EU single market rules - forcing checks on manufactured and agricultural products crossing the Irish Sea.

The Northern Ireland Assembly - known as Stormont - will get a vote every four years on whether to let EU law continue. But this vote could be passed by a simple majority - denying the DUP a veto on staying under EU laws long-term.

Meanwhile commitments on workers' rights are deprioritised - moved to the non-legally-binding Political Declaration for agreement later.
